user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy (size_t size,
                                      const void *buffer)
{
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  void *mhd_copy;

  if (0 == size)
    return MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (0,
                                                                   NULL,
                                                                   NULL,
                                                                   NULL);
  if (NULL == buffer)
    return NULL;

  mhd_copy = malloc (size);
  if (NULL == mhd_copy)
    return NULL;
  memcpy (mhd_copy, buffer, size);

  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size,
                                                              mhd_copy,
                                                              &free,
                                                              mhd_copy);
  if (NULL == r)
    free (mhd_copy);
  else
  {
    /* TODO: remove the next assignment, the buffer should not be modifiable */
    r->data_buffer_size = size;
  }

  return r;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other constructs in the snippet are standard C and not compiler-specific language extensions. Examples include: use of standard types (size_t), storage/class specifiers (struct), pointer and const qualifiers (const void *buffer), standard library functions and expressions (malloc, memcpy, free, NULL), taking a function address (e.g. &free), pointer member access (r->data_buffer_size), return and if statements, and block comments. The function call to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls and identifiers with leading underscores are ordinary identifiers/macros in source code; they are not by themselves language extensions. Therefore they do not need further investigation for compiler-specific language-extension usage. The only token that may expand to a compiler-specific extension is the identifier _MHD_EXTERN (commonly a macro that can map to __attribute__ or __declspec); that is why the function declaration line containing _MHD_EXTERN is reported for investigation.
